metadata.author: Eric J. Rubin, Lindsey R. Baden, Stephen Morrissey, Edward W. Campion
metadata.title: Medical Journals and the 2019-nCoV Outbreak
metadata.abstract: At the Journal, we work with authors to craft their messages to provide readers the best information from rigorous medical practice and basic science. The process can take time, with careful peer review, editing, and graphics often involving multiple rounds of revision. This work fulfills our mission: to provide our readers with the highest-quality information to guide the care of patients.

introduction: At the Journal, we work with authors to craft their messages to provide readers the best information from rigorous medical practice and basic science. The process can take time, with careful peer review, editing, and graphics often involving multiple rounds of revision. This work fulfills our mission: to provide our readers with the highest-quality information to guide the care of patients.

But some situations call for a different approach. The current outbreak of coronavirus infection is a threat to the health of the public and a breaking news story that changes hour by hour. We can eventually take a long view of how to manage and prevent epidemics, but today practitioners and public health authorities need actionable information as soon as possible.

summary: At the Journal, the authors work with authors to craft their messages to provide readers the best information from rigorous medical practice and basic science.
The process can take time, with careful peer review, editing, and graphics often involving multiple rounds of revision.
This work fulfills the mission: to provide the readers with the highest-quality information to guide the care of patients.
Some situations call for a different approach.
The current outbreak of coronavirus infection is a threat to the health of the public and a breaking news story that changes hour by hour.
The authors can eventually take a long view of how to manage and prevent epidemics, but today practitioners and public health authorities need actionable information as soon as possible.
The authors are putting in place a set of practices that the authors will apply to all submitted manuscripts describing the 2019-nCoV outbreak.
The authors expect authors to share important information with public health authorities as early as possible.
In the case of the current coronavirus outbreak, the authors will, with authors’ approval, share appropriate manuscripts in confidence with the World Health Organization.
The authors encourage authors to submit their work for posting on preprint servers.
The authors will rapidly evaluate submitted manuscripts and, if the authors plan to publish them, will expedite all editorial steps to make them available as quickly as possible.
The authors encourage authors to share with other researchers the original data that underlie all reports on 2019-nCoV that the authors publish.
As with all work with immediate public health significance, articles about the coronavirus outbreak will be made freely available at NEJM.org from the day of publication.
A special page has been created at NEJM.org for all coronavirus articles, along with links to essential resources for clinicians.

Because the authors cannot publish everything the authors receive, the authors will, on manuscript submission, offer authors the opportunity for rapid transfer of their manuscript to other participating journals, with reviewer comments when available.
The rapid pace of infectious disease outbreaks can be frightening.
The authors' aim is to transparently bring readers the best information available in a highly expedited manner.
Disclosure forms provided by the authors are available with the full text of this editorial at NEJM.org.
